content: The "Rio Grande Natural Area Act" establishes the Rio Grande Natural Area, with definitions for terms like Commission and Secretary. The Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado is established to conserve natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources along the Rio Grande River. Boundaries extend from the Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge to the New Mexico State border. The Secretary will create a map and legal description of the area. The Secretary will prepare a map and legal description of the Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado, which will have the same legal force as if included in the Act. The map will be available for public inspection at Bureau of Land Management offices. Establishment of the Commission. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission is established to advise the Secretary on the Natural Area and prepare a management plan for non-Federal land. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Bureau of Land Management and the Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge manager. Three members are appointed based on the recommendation of the Governor of Colorado. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Bureau of Land Management and the Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge manager. Three members are appointed based on the recommendation of the Governor of Colorado, representing the Colorado Division of Wildlife, Colorado Division of Water Resources, and Rio Grande Water Conservation District. Four members represent the general public and have knowledge and experience in preservation, restoration, and use of the area. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Bureau of Land Management and the Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge manager. Members must have knowledge and experience in preservation, restoration, and use of the area. The term of office for a member is 5 years, with the possibility of reappointment. Members serve without compensation and elect a chairperson. The Commission elects a chairperson and holds quarterly public meetings. Notice of meetings must be published in advance. The Secretary and other agencies provide technical assistance as requested. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, meetings, and take testimony to carry out the Act. They can also enter into cooperative agreements with the State of Colorado or other entities for managing non-Federal land in the Natural Area. The Commission can enter into cooperative agreements with the State of Colorado or other entities to manage non-Federal land in the Natural Area. Procedures for notice of proposed actions affecting the management plan must be established. Cooperative agreements do not change Federal agency rights or duties under Federal law. The Commission is prohibited from acquiring real property. The Commission can assist the Secretary in implementing the management plan for the Natural Area by preserving and interpreting its resources. This includes helping Colorado preserve State land and wildlife within the area. The Commission can assist the State of Colorado in preserving State land and wildlife within the Natural Area, increasing public awareness of the area's resources, encouraging land use policies consistent with the management plan, and assisting private landowners in the area. The Commission aims to assist in preserving State land and wildlife in the Natural Area, increasing public awareness, promoting land use policies aligned with the management plan, and supporting private landowners in implementing the plan. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Secretary and the Commission, along with relevant agencies and landowners, must prepare management plans for the Natural Area within 4 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will focus on Federal land, while the Commission will address non-Federal land. The Commission is responsible for preparing a management plan for non-Federal land in the Natural Area, which must be submitted to the Secretary for approval or disapproval. If the plan is disapproved, the Secretary will take action accordingly. If the management plan for non-Federal land in the Natural Area is disapproved, the Commission must notify the Commission of the reasons and allow for revisions to be submitted. The Secretary and the Commission must cooperate to ensure consistent management plans for Federal and non-Federal land in the Natural Area. The management plans should consider existing Federal, State, and local plans to create a unified preservation, restoration, and conservation plan. Federal land management plans must comply with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The Natural Area management plan must comply with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, be consistent with adjacent land management plans, and be considered an amendment to the San Luis Resource Management Plan. It should include an inventory of resources and property actions for preservation, restoration, and development. The management plan for the Natural Area should include a list of property actions for preservation, restoration, and development, along with policies for resource management to protect the resources and natural values of the area. The Secretary is required to publish notice of the management plans in the Federal Register. The administration of the natural area is outlined in Section 7. The Secretary administers the Federal land in the Natural Area in accordance with laws, regulations, and the management plan. This includes conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources, as well as allowing for education, scientific study, and limited public recreation without substantially impairing the area's purposes. The Natural Area is managed by the Secretary to conserve natural resources and allow for education, scientific study, and limited public recreation. This includes protecting wildlife habitat, prohibiting water storage facilities, reducing roads, and limiting motorized vehicle use. The management plan for the Natural Area includes prohibiting motorized vehicles on Federal land west of the Rio Grande River and negotiating streamflow changes with Colorado and water users. Private land in the area is subject to the same management plan. The management plan for the Natural Area includes restrictions on motorized vehicles on Federal land west of the Rio Grande River and negotiating streamflow changes with Colorado and water users. Private land in the area is also subject to the management plan, but only if the private landowner agrees in writing. Federal land in the Natural Area is withdrawn from various activities under public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws, with exceptions for valid existing rights. The Secretary may acquire land from willing sellers. The Secretary may acquire land in the Natural Area from willing sellers through purchase, exchange, or donation, to be administered according to the management plan and this Act. Section 5(d)(1) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act does not apply to the Natural Area. SEC. 8. EFFECT. The Act does not amend the Rio Grande Compact, regulate private land in the Natural Area, impose mandatory streamflow requirements, create Federal water rights, enforce stricter water quality standards, or prevent Colorado from acquiring instream rights. The Act does not prevent Colorado from acquiring an instream flow through the Natural Area under State law to protect the environment. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out the Act, and the Commission will terminate 10 years after its enactment.
